quoteFirst: At noon the Battle Fleet was in Lat. 58.21 N., Long. 1.12 E., zigzagging at a speed of 15 knots, and the 4th Battle Squadron had just been detached to proceed to Cromarty, when at
quoteLast: Vice-Admiral Sir Cecil Burney commanding the 1st Battle Squadron signalled that a submarine’s periscope had been sighted from the _Marlborough_, the leading ship of the port wing column, and that a torpedo fired by the submarine had passed just astern of the _Neptune_, the rear ship of the column.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteLast: the _New York_ having discontinued fire at Aguadores, commenced firing 8-inch shells clear over the gully into the city of Santiago de Cuba. Every five minutes the shells went roaring over the hillside.
title: The Boys of '98
author: Otis, James, 1848-1912

quoteFirst: _Alyssum_, one of Admiral Bayly’s sloops based on Queenstown, who was escorting the large four-masted S.S. _Canadian_. As _Penshurst_ proceeded, she sighted at
quoteLast: a boat with men in it, these being from the torpedoed sailing ship _Invercauld_, which had been sunk 22 miles S.E. of Mine Head, Ireland, that same day. A few minutes later and _Penshurst_ observed the keel of this ship floating bottom up.
title: Q-Ships and Their Story
author: Chatterton, E. Keble (Edward Keble), 1878-1944

quoteFirst: A twenty-five feet stage was erected in a stubble ground without the slightest interruption. Cribb’s second was his old friend and intimate companion Gully, and Joe Ward bottle-holder; Bill Richmond and Bill Gibbons officiated for Molineaux. At
quoteLast: they set-to; betting three to one on Cribb, and six to four in his favour for the first knock-down blow.
title:
Pugilistica: The History of British Boxing, Volume 1 (of 3)
Containing Lives of the Most Celebrated Pugilists; Full Reports of Their Battles from Contemporary Newspapers, With Authentic Portraits, Personal Anecdotes, and Sketches of the Principal Patrons of the Prize Ring, Forming a Complete History of the Ring from Fig and Broughton, 1719-40, to the Last Championship Battle Between King and Heenan, in December 1863
author: Miles, Henry Downes, 1806-1889

quoteFirst: Thus not one occurred for Paris during the whole of the nineteenth century, the last which happened exactly above the capital of France having been on May 22, 1724. quoteLast: (total for Choisy-le-Roi, Longjumeau, and Dourdan, but very brief: seven seconds), and August 11, 1999, at 10.28 A.M. (total for Beauvais, Compiègne, Amiens, St.
title: Astronomy for Amateurs
